Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Structure and Tone in Luyia

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
How and why do languages vary? Studying closely related languages can tell us important details of the nature of human language, by holding most grammatical properties constant while varying others, across a set of languages. Understanding the limits on such variation and how such differences arise historically requires an accurate description of a group of related languages.

The heterogeneous varieties of Luyia, a group of Bantu languages of Kenya and Uganda, provide a laboratory for investigating such micro-variation in grammar. This project will produce the first comprehensive descriptions and formal analyses of four underdocumented Kenyan varieties of Luyia: Bukusu, Logoori, Tiriki, and Wanga. A series of monographs will be developed for each language which include a grammatical outline, a detailed description of the tonal system, in-depth studies in syntax, a collection of texts, and a dictionary.

The diverse tone systems of Luyia are a major focus of this work. Luyia tone has many notable features, including a rare process by which High tones spread leftward across and within words. Complex tonal patterns mark inflectional differences among verb tenses, and syntactically conditioned rules are also found in the phrasal tonology. A solid understanding of these processes bears crucially on theories of the phonology-syntax interface, which are concerned with what kind of syntactic information can be used by a phonological system. These theoretically and typologically interesting features of Luyia tone will be systematically investigated through targeted paradigmatic elicitation.

This project models team-based, data-rich and theoretically informed linguistic description and analysis. The Luyia team draws on the expertise of linguists in multiple subfields and brings together US-based and Africa-based scholars, enriching the practice of linguistics by each group. The monographs, text collections, and dictionaries produced by the project will be made freely available online, and relevant materials will be disseminated within the appropriate local communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative research: Structure and tone in Luyia has succeeded in documenting and describing four understudied languages of the Luyia language cluster in western Kenya (Bukusu, Logoori, Tiriki, and Wanga). This report focuses on the contributions of co-PIs Marlo and Odden at the University of Missouri.

Over the 5 years of this grant (2014-2020), a huge amount of data on each of the four languages has been collected, expanding the empirical base of the field. Our project provides a model for the detailed investigation of African and Bantu languages, using a team-based approach investigating several closely related linguistic varieties. The main written products our work has developed are talking dictionaries, corpora of oral literature, grammars, and monographs on tone. Our research actitivies have also contributed to the education and training of students and the practice of linguistics in Kenya.

Talking dictionaries have been developed for each language with over 4000 words and audio recordings exemplifying the pronunciations of each word. These dictionaries, which are some of the most extensive tone-marked, phonetically transcribed wordlists for any Bantu languages, currently exist as electronic resources that are publically available. They are being prepared for online publication in the journal Dictionaria.

Large corpora of oral literature were developed for Bukusu (85 new narratives, 30 hours of audio recordings), Logoori (150 new narratives, 40 hours of audio), Tiriki (180 new narratives, 43 hours of audio), and Wanga (125 new narratives, 20 hours of audio). Considerable resources have been devoted to the transcription, translation, and interlinear analysis of the texts in each corpus, which will be prepared for publication upon completion of our grammars.

Using the text collections and other materials collected through questionnaires and interviews with speakers, our team has developed numerous chapters for grammars of each language. The University of Missouri team has focused primarily on topics in phonology and morphology. Our partners at Pomona College have carried out the bulk of the research on Luyia syntax, and Green (Syracuse) has collaborated on all aspects of research on Wanga. At the time of this report, we have made significant progress towards book-length grammatical descriptions of each language, with Wanga currently closest to publication.

A primary research focus of the Missouri team has been on phonology and especially tone. Odden’s research on Logoori has generated a 200-page description of Logoori segmental phonology, and more than 300 pages on tonal phonology. Marlo has developed studies of comparable depth investigating the tonal systems of Bukusu, Tiriki, and Wanga. The publication of the monographs on Luyia tone are the Missouri team’s highest post-grant publication priority.

The documentation, description, and analysis of Luyia tone systems is generating some of the most comprehensive work on tone in the Bantu linguistics literature. As this work has evolved alongside research on Luyia syntax, it has set up future research opportunities in tone-syntax interactions. The parallel development of our research on four languages has also enabled us to begin comparative and historical linguistic investigations to reveal how Luyia tonal systems have changed over time.

Over the past five years, more than 50 University of Missouri undergraduates have participated on the “Documenting Luyia Together” research team. Students used software like Audacity to process audio recordings, Praat to phonetically transcribe utterances, Overleaf to typeset chapters in LaTeX, and Fieldworks Language Explorer to build and analyze our oral literature collections. Students also carried out bibliographic research, drafted grammar chapters on topics in Luyia phonology, morphology, and syntax, carried out a study of Luyia language vitality, and developed a new phylogenetic classification of Luyia languages. Seven of Marlo’s students wrote undergraduate honors theses on topics in Luyia phonology and morphosyntax.

Our project has collaborated extensively with Kenyan linguists and language activists. Marlo spent 5 months in 2016 as a Fulbright scholar at Kenyatta University, where he offered courses in phonology and linguistic field methods, worked closely with graduate students and faculty, and organized a workshop on studying tone in African languages, while carrying out research on Luyia dictionaries and tone systems. Odden has consulted with the Maragoli Journal and other Logoori language enthusiasts who are encouraging orthography reform and the practice of development of written materials in the Logoori language.

The project developed a network of researchers with interests in Luyia linguistics. This network includes Luyia-speaking Kenyan scholars in linguistics and education, linguists in the US who have developed the most extensive grammatical and lexicographic studies of Luyia languages to date, and researchers from Ghent University who have modeled gold-standard practices in the development of African language corpora, grammars, and dictionaries and who have pioneered the development of pedagogical grammars, reading materials, and teacher training programs in Uganda. The network submitted grant proposals to the PEER program and Firebird Foundation to build on the results of this grant to contribute to development aims, supporting literacy in childhood education.
